 Paul Dominic writes:
	
	              If you are generating JUnit Report =
through Ant,
definitely you
	should write one build.xml file. Before genera=
ting new report,
why not you
	take copy of the previous report.  In Ant API=
  contains copy tag
and move
	tag. So
	first step you take a back up using =
Copy/ Move tag.
	Second step you clear your old report using delete tag.
	T=
hird step create report folder again.
	Finally you generate new report.

Ar=
e you saying there's no extension for JUnit that sends the test
results/rep=
ort into a database, using JDBC or some other mechanism?  I'm
new to JUnit,=
 too, but I find it hard to believe that there isn't
already software to st=
ore historical test results in a database.


Todd.
